questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with localized pain, which is gradual in onset and worsened over time. X-ray showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteosarcoma is a common primary bone tumor that often presents in adolescents and young adults with localized pain that worsens over time. It is typically seen in the metaphysis of long bones, and the X-ray findings often show a characteristic "sunburst" pattern or Codman's triangle.



 

Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma):

  • Most common primary malignant bone tumor of non-hematopoietic origin/ solid malignant bone tumor.
  • Age group: Bimodal age distribution peaking in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade.
  • Gender: Males >> Female

 

Pathology:

  • Origin: It arises from mesenchymal cells.
  • Common site: From the metaphysis or meta-diaphysis.
  • Order of frequency: Lower-end of the femur > upper-end of the tibia > upper-end of the humerus.

  • All osteosarcomas are aggressive and metastasize widely through the hematogenous route, typically to the lungs.
  • Despite its aggressiveness, it seldom penetrates the epiphyseal plate.

 

Histopathology: Anaplastic mesenchymal parenchyma with tumor cells surrounded by osteoid.

 

Clinical manifestation:

  • Worsening pain and swelling, particularly night pain.
  • Pathological fracture is rare.
  • On examination:
    • Shiny skin with prominent veins over swelling.
    • Poorly defined, warm, and tender swelling.
    • Adjacent joint movement may be limited due to swelling.
    • The tumor may compress neurovascular structures, causing symptoms.
    • Usually reactive enlargement of regional lymph nodes.
  • Associated syndromes with osteosarcoma development:
    • Li–Fraumeni (p53 tumor suppressor gene mutation)
    • Hereditary retinoblastoma syndromes
    • Rothmund–Thomson syndrome

X-ray findings of osteosarcoma:

  • Area of irregular destruction in the metaphysis. The cortex overlying the lesion is eroded.

Sun-ray appearance (aggressive periostitis): As the tumor grows into the overlying soft tissues new bone is laid down centrifugally along the blood vessels within the tumor.

  • Codman's triangle: Elevation of periosteum by the growing tumor in the form of a triangle. (Option C)

 

CT scan is primarily used to assist with biopsy and disease staging.

 

Treatment

Combination of therapy:

  • Surgical amputation is the treatment of choice- complete removal of the tumor must be ensured. Limb-salvage procedures have become possible and popular.
  • Radiotherapy
  • Chemotherapy
    • Doxorubicin
    • Cisplatin
    • Ifosfamide
    • Methotrexate
  • Follow-up: Every 6-8 weeks. Evidence of recurrence of the primary tumor or appearance of the secondary (usually in the chest) is diagnosed early and treated.





 

Option B: Ewing sarcoma

  • Typically occurs in children and adolescents.
  • More common in the diaphysis of long bones (e.g., femur, pelvis).
  • X-ray shows an onion-skin (lamellated) periosteal reaction and moth-eaten appearance due to aggressive bone destruction.
  • Associated with t(11;22) translocation.

Option C: Chondrosarcoma

  • More common in older adults (>40 years).
  • Arises in the pelvis, femur, or proximal humerus.
  • X-ray shows a rings and arcs (popcorn) calcification pattern due to cartilaginous matrix production.

Option D: Gout

  • A metabolic disorder causing monosodium urate crystal deposition.
  • Typically affects the 1st metatarsophalangeal joint (podagra) but can involve other joints.

X-ray findings include punched-out erosions with overhanging edges (rat-bite lesions), not the characteristic periosteal reactions seen in osteosarcoma.

questions.text: Identify the following condition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Osteosarcoma

Explanation:

Osteosarcoma is the most common type of cancer occurring in long bones and it's common amongst children in 2nd decade.

  • It is a metaphyseal tumor, usually located at Distal end of femur. It has a bimodal presentation and is the most radioresistant tumor
  • Characteristics: Codman triangle as seen in image (from elevation of periosteum) or sunburst pattern on x-ray (think of an osteocod [bone fish] swimming in the sun).
  • Treatment; Neoadjuvent chemotherapy followed by surgery/ limb ablation.

 

Ewing Sarcoma (Option B): Although Ewing sarcoma is also a bone-mediated tumor, it commonly affects pelvis, ribs, spine and long bones as opposed to Osteosarcoma which only affects the long bones of the arms and legs and the x-ray image is of the femur.

 

Osteiod Osteoma (Option C): In case of Osteiod Osteoma the x-ray imaging shows presence of nidus surrounded by sclerosis, which is not indicating the x-ray image.

 

GCT (Option D): Giant Cell Tumors are typically found at the ends of the long bones and extend into the epiphysis to surface of the joint, whereas the images show a tumor which is not located at the end of the bone.

questions.text: A 35 year old man presented with a gradual progressive swelling, and was diagnosed with Adamantinoma. Which of the following bones is typically affected by this tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tibia

Explanation:

  • The tibia is the most common site for adamantinoma, particularly the anterior metaphysis or diaphysis. This predilection is due to the close proximity of the tibia's enchondral bone to the skin, which supports the embryological displacement theory.

Adamantinoma

About
  • Rare, low-grade malignant bone tumors of uncertain histogenesis
  • Commonly affects the anterior metaphysis and diaphysis tibia, close to the skin surface.
  • Immunohistochemical studies suggest epithelial origin.
  • Commonly affects individuals aged 20-40 years.

Histopathology
  • Macroscopic: Well-defined, lobulated cortical tumors with yellowish-gray appearance and possible cystic spaces.
  • Microscopic: Biphasic composition (epithelial and osteofibrous components) with basaloid, tubular, spindle-cell, squamous, and osteofibrous dysplasia-like patterns.
  • Immunohistochemistry:
    • Epithelial cells: Positive for keratin, EMA, vimentin, p63, podoplanin.
    • Fibrous component: Positive for vimentin.
    • Expression of EGF, EGFR (epithelial), FGF2, FGFR1 (both components).

Clinical Features
  • Prolonged clinical course with slow-growing swelling, possible pain, bone deformities, or pathological fractures (~23%).
  • Rarely involves neurological deficits when the spine is affected.
  • Metastases commonly involve lungs, lymph nodes, or spine.

Evaluation
  • X-ray: Well-circumscribed, multilobulated, osteolytic cortical tumor with a "soap-bubble" appearance.
  • CT Scan: Assesses soft tissue extension and cortical involvement.
  • MRI: Locoregional staging; visualizes tumor margins, cortical involvement, and soft tissue extension.

Treatment
  • Wide Resection: En bloc removal with wide margins preferred.
  • Metastasectomy: First-line for pulmonary recurrences.

 

Radius (Option A): Although adamantinoma can rarely occur in the radius, it is an atypical site. The tibia remains the most frequently affected bone.

Humerus (Option B): Adamantinoma seldom affects the humerus. It primarily involves long bones of the lower limb, with the tibia being the most common.

Femur (Option C) can be involved in rare cases, but it is far less commonly affected than the tibia.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old female who presents with a tumor located at the knee joint, as shown in the provided biopsy-image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Giant cell tumour

Explanation:

  • Clinical scenario and biopsy image showing multinucleated giant cells in the background of spindle cells is suggestive of Giant cell tumor/Osteoclastoma (GCT).

Osteoclastoma/ Giant Cell Tumor:

Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > Proximal tibia > Distal radius > Sacrum

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Histo- pathology
  • Multinucleated giant cells and a background network of spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells.

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

Incorrect Options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A): Sunburst appearance on X-ray, seen in children. Biopsy shows cellular pleomorphism, osteoid formation with increased mitotic activity.

Ewing’s Sarcoma (Option B): Associated with fever, Onion peel appearance on x-ray. Small round blue cells, homer-wright rosettes are seen on biopsy.

Osteoblastoma (Option D): Decreased cellularity with lack of necrosis surrounding a well vascularised stroma on biopsy is suggestive of Osteoblastoma.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is experiencing pain in the area surrounding his knee joint. The following lesion visible on the X-ray is seen extending from the distal femur to the terminal end. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Osteosarcoma

Explanation:

  • Based on the demographics of the patient, clinical manifestation, and X-ray showing sunburst appearance, the most probable diagnosis is osteosarcoma. It most commonly originates in the metaphysis of long bones.

Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma):

  • Most common primary malignant bone tumor of non-hematopoietic origin/ solid malignant bone tumor.
  • Age group: Bimodal age distribution peaking in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade.
  • Gender: Males >> Female

Pathology:

  • Origin: It arises from mesenchymal cells.
  • Common site: From the metaphysis or meta-diaphysis
  • Order of frequency: Lower-end of the femur > upper-end of the tibia > upper-end of the humerus.
Types base on Clinical Setting 

Primary osteosarcoma 

  • No known pre-malignant conditions related to it. 
  • Age group: 15-25 years

Secondary osteosarcoma 

  • Pre-malignant conditions are often associated with it. 
  • Paget's disease, multiple enchondromatosis, fibrous dysplasia, irradiation to bones, multiple osteochondroma. 
  • Older age group

 

  • All osteosarcomas are aggressive and metastasize widely through the hematogenous route, typically to the lungs.
  • Despite its aggressiveness, it seldom penetrates the epiphyseal plate.

Histopathology: Anaplastic mesenchymal parenchyma with tumor cells surrounded by osteoid.

Clinical manifestation:

  • Worsening pain and swelling, particularly night pain.
  • Pathological fracture is rare.
  • On examination:
    • Shiny skin with prominent veins over swelling.
    • Poorly defined, warm, and tender swelling.
    • Adjacent joint movement may be limited due to swelling.
    • The tumor may compress neurovascular structures, causing symptoms.
    • Usually reactive enlargement of regional lymph nodes.
  • Associated syndromes with osteosarcoma development:
    • Li–Fraumeni (p53 tumor suppressor gene mutation)
    • Hereditary retinoblastoma syndromes
    • Rothmund–Thomson syndrome

X-ray findings of osteosarcoma:

  • Area of irregular destruction in the metaphysis. The cortex overlying the lesion is eroded.
  • Sun-ray appearance (aggressive periostitis): As the tumor grows into the overlying soft tissues new bone is laid down centrifugally along the blood vessels within the tumor.

 

 

  • Codman's triangle: Elevation of periosteum by the growing tumor in the form of a triangle.

CT scan is primarily used to assist with biopsy and disease staging.

Incorrect Options:

Giant Cell Tumor (Option A):

  • Benign but aggressive tumor, typically affecting older adolescents/adults.
  • Seen in the epiphysis, not typically with the "sunburst" appearance.
  • Usually localized, not extending aggressively like osteosarcoma.

Chondroblastoma (Option B):

  • Benign tumor, usually in the epiphysis of long bones.
  • Common in adolescents but lacks aggressive features like periosteal reactions seen in osteosarcoma.

Osteoid Osteoma (Option C):

  • Benign tumor causing localized pain, often relieved by NSAIDs.
  • Small lesion with central nidus and sclerosis, no aggressive periosteal reaction.

questions.text: A 28-year old male with gradual progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Image of the swelling on the x-ray film is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Osteoclastoma

Explanation:

  • Clinical scenario and x-ray showing eccentric expansile lytic lesion on epiphysis is suggestive of Giant cell tumor/Osteoclastoma (GCT). Management of GCT is Extended curettage and Bone grafting.

Osteoclastoma/ Giant Cell Tumor:

Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum.

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Histo- pathology
  • Multinucleated giant cells and a background network of spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells.

 

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

 

Incorrect options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A):

  • Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and adolescents. It typically presents with pain and swelling, often in the long bones, such as the tibia. Radiographic features may include bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.
  • X-ray: Bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.

Ewing's sarcoma (Option B):

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant bone tumor that primarily affects children and adolescents. It commonly presents with pain, swelling, and a palpable mass.
  • Radiographic features may show a permeative bone destruction, onion skin appearance, and soft tissue involvement.

 

Osteochondroma (Option D):

  • The most common bone tumor (not a True bone tumor), usually presents as a painless lump.
  • Radiography shows sessile pedunculated cartilage tumor covered by a cartilage cap originating from the metaphysis.
  • Cartilage thickness > 2 cms is suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text:
Match the following with their most appropriate mode of management:

 


	
		
			
			1. Osteosarcoma

			2. Simple bone cyst

			3. Giant cell tumor

			4. Osteoid osteoma
			
			
			A. Wide excision

			B. Curettage

			C. Radiofrequency ablation

			D. Intralesional steroid
questions.solution:
Condition

Features and Findings

Treatment

Osteosarcoma
  • A malignant bone tumor, commonly affecting the metaphyses of long bones (e.g., femur, tibia).
  • It most frequently occurs in adolescents and young adults. Symptoms include pain, swelling, and sometimes a palpable mass.
  • X-rays typically show a sunburst appearance with mixed lytic and sclerotic areas.
  • Surgical resection (amputation or limb-sparing surgery), followed by chemotherapy.
  • Radiation therapy is rarely used.

Simple Bone Cyst

  • A benign, fluid-filled cyst, often occurring in the proximal humerus or femur.
  • It is typically asymptomatic
  • On X-ray, it appears as a well-defined, cystic lesion with a thin cortical rim.
  • Often occurs in children and adolescents.
  • Aspiration and steroid injection, or curettage with bone grafting if recurrent fractures occur.
  • Surgical intervention is usually necessary if there is risk of fracture.

Giant Cell Tumor

  • A benign, locally aggressive tumor that typically occurs in the epiphysis of long bones (e.g., distal femur, proximal tibia).
  • It is most common in young adults.
  • Symptoms include pain, swelling, and sometimes joint dysfunction.
  • X-rays show a lytic lesion with a "soap bubble" appearance.
  • Curettage with bone grafting or chemical adjuvants (e.g., phenol). Wide resection for larger or more aggressive tumors..

Osteoid Osteoma
  • A benign bone tumor that most commonly affects the femur or tibia. It typically occurs in adolescents or young adults.
  • Characterized by a small, well-circumscribed lesion with a central nidus on X-ray.
  • Symptoms include localized pain, especially at night, that is relieved by NSAIDs.
  • Surgical excision of the nidus is the standard treatment. Radiofrequency ablation can be used
  • Pain is often well-controlled with NSAIDs until definitive treatment.

questions.text: A 30-year old male with gradual progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Image of the swelling on the x-ray film is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Osteoclastoma

Explanation:

Clinical scenario and x-ray showing eccentric expansile lytic lesion on epiphysis is suggestive of Giant cell tumor/Osteoclastoma (GCT). Management of GCT is Extended curettage and Bone grafting.

Osteoclastoma/ Giant Cell Tumor:

Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum.

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Histo- pathology
  • Multinucleated giant cells and a background network of spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells.

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

 

Incorrect options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A):

  • Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and adolescents. It typically presents with pain and swelling, often in the long bones, such as the tibia. Radiographic features may include bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.
  • X-ray: Bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.

 

Ewing's sarcoma (Option B):

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant bone tumor that primarily affects children and adolescents. It commonly presents with pain, swelling, and a palpable mass.
  • Radiographic features may show a permeative bone destruction, onion skin appearance, and soft tissue involvement.

 

Osteochondroma (Option D):

  • The most common bone tumor (not a True bone tumor), usually presents as a painless lump.
  • Radiography shows sessile pedunculated cartilage tumor covered by a cartilage cap originating from the metaphysis.
  • Cartilage thickness > 2 cms is suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling around her wrist joint for 3 months. Given below is the image of the X-ray film. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Osteoclastoma

 

Explanation:

Clinical scenario and x-ray showing eccentric expansile lytic lesion on epiphysis is suggestive of Giant cell tumor/Osteoclastoma (GCT). Management of GCT is Extended curettage and Bone grafting.

Osteoclastoma/ Giant Cell Tumor:

Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum.

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Histo- pathology
  • Multinucleated giant cells and a background network of spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells.

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

Incorrect options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A):

  • Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and adolescents. It typically presents with pain and swelling, often in the long bones, such as the tibia. Radiographic features may include bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.
  • X-ray: Bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.

Ewing's sarcoma (Option B):

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant bone tumor that primarily affects children and adolescents. It commonly presents with pain, swelling, and a palpable mass.
  • Radiographic features may show a permeative bone destruction, onion skin appearance, and soft tissue involvement.

Osteochondroma (Option D):

  • The most common bone tumor (not a True bone tumor), usually presents as a painless lump.
  • Radiography shows sessile pedunculated cartilage tumor covered by a cartilage cap originating from the metaphysis.
  • Cartilage thickness > 2 cms is suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with knee pain. The x-ray of his knee joint is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Osteoclastoma. Osteoclastoma, also known as a giant cell tumor, is a locally aggressive and destructive bone tumor that is composed of multinucleated giant cells and stromal cells.

  • Osteoclastoma is most commonly seen in the epiphysis or metaphysis of long bones such as the distal femur, proximal tibia, and distal radius.

 

  • Soap bubble appearance is the characteristic radiological finding of giant cell tumors.
  • It presents as a lytic lesion with multiple internal septations, giving it a soap bubble appearance. It is usually located in the epiphysis of long bones, such as the distal femur.

 

X-ray findings in Giant cell tumors (GCTs):

  • Eccentric location, often subchondral.
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex.
  • The cortex may be thinned out.

Lobulated lytic lesions with narrow zones of transition produce a soap bubble appearance.

  • No calcification within the tumor.
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.
  • The tumor usually does not enter the adjacent joint.

 

Treatment:

  • The treatment of choice is excision.
  • Followed by reconstruction procedures and bone grafting or polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) insertion.
  • Adjuvant treatments:
    • Liquid nitrogen and phenol have been shown to decrease recurrences.
    • Bisphosphonates like zoledronate or pamidronate
  • Radiotherapy- especially for spine GCTs
  • Drugs:

Denosumab- anti-RANKL monoclonal antibody.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with painful swelling in the index finger around the proximal phalanx. An X-ray was done, and it is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Enchondroma

Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows a radiolucent (dark) lesion with stippled (small, white, calcified) areas in the proximal phalanx of the finger.
  • Chondroma is a benign tumour of hyaline cartilage that occurs in bones of endochondral origin.
  • Tumours can arise within the medullary cavity, called enchondromas or on the bone surface, where they are called juxtacortical chondromas.
  • It is the most common type of benign bone tumor of the phalanges of the hand and is usually seen in 10 to 30 years of age.
  • Both Maffucci syndrome and Ollier’s disease are characterised by multiple enchondromas (not solitary).
  • Treatment: Curettage with wall cauterization.

 

 

Osteosarcoma (Option A) is a malignant bone tumor more commonly seen in young adults' metaphyseal region of long bones. On an X-ray, it usually appears as a mixed radiolucent-radiopaque lesion with a sunburst pattern.

 

Megaloblastic anaemia (Option A) The main causes are folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. Peripheral blood shows hypersegmented neutrophils and macroovalocytes as early changes. Bone marrow is hypercellular, with numerous megaloblasts and giant metamyelocytes.

 

Ewing's Sarcoma (Option B) is a malignant bone tumor more commonly seen in young adults' diaphyseal region of long bones. On an X-ray, it usually appears as a permeative lesion with onion peel appearance.

 

Osteoclastoma (Option C), or giant cell tumor, is a benign bone tumor more commonly seen in young adults with epiphysis of long bones. An X-ray shows an eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis and a typical soap bubble appearance.

questions.text: Fracture after trivial fall in elderly patient. Identify the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Bone metastasis

Explanation:

Bony metastasis is the most common cause of pathological fracture in elderly.

Metastatic Tumors to Bone

Common Metastatic Tumors
  • Lung carcinoma (male)
  • Breast carcinoma (female)
  • Prostate carcinoma (Osteoblastic)
  • Thyroid carcinoma

Clinical Features
  • Known Primary Malignancy:
    • Bone pain (common in spine, ribs, extremities)
    • Pathological fracture (common in spine and hip)
 
  • Unknown Primary Malignancy:
    • Bone pain leading to destructive lesion diagnosis
    • Pathological fracture due to weakened bone

Malignancies Presenting with Silent Primary
  • Thyroid carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Bladder carcinoma

Common Sites of Metastasis
  • Vertebral bodies
  • Ribs
  • Pelvis (Option A)
  • Humerus
  • Femur
  • Uncommon distal to elbow and knee

TB hip (Option B) generally causes chronic symptoms such as pain, swelling, and stiffness, and may eventually lead to deformity of the hip joint.

  • TB hip would present with more severe symptoms prior to a fracture.

A brown tumour (Option C) is associated with hyperparathyroidism, which causes bone resorption and weakening.

  • They are typically associated with chronic conditions like primary hyperparathyroidism or secondary hyperparathyroidism

Eosinophilic granuloma (a form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis) (Option D) is a rare condition more commonly seen in children or young adults.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with pain and swelling over the distal radius. X-ray shows an expansile lytic lesion in the metaphysis. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) reveals a bloody aspirate with hemosiderin-laden macrophages. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aneurysmal bone cyst

 

Explanation:

  • An aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is often characterized by an expansile, lytic lesion, and its FNA typically yields a bloody aspirate due to the cystic, vascular nature of the lesion.
  • Hemosiderin-laden macrophages are commonly seen due to prior hemorrhage within the cyst.

 

Giant cell tumor (GCT) (Option A) can also present as an expansile lytic lesion, but it usually involves the epiphysis without such a significant cystic, vascular component or bloody aspirate on FNA.

 

 

Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC)

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT)

Age

Primarily affects children and teenagers

Most common in young adults (15-35 years)

Gender

Equal distribution between males and females

More common in females (Female: Male ratio 1.5:1)

Location

Metaphyses of long bones (femur, tibia, humerus), spine

Epiphyses of long bones (lower end of femur, upper end of tibia)

Symptoms

Pain and swelling; spinal lesions may cause neurological issues

Swelling without pain; late stages show joint limitation and pathological fracture

Histology
  • FNAC: Hemosiderin +
  • Blood-filled cystic spaces separated by fibrous septae
  • FNAC: No hemosiderin
  • Abundant giant cells with multiple nuclei (>150), spindle cells indicating malignancy

Radiology

Osteolytic lesion, multiple septations and fluid-fluid levels on MRI

Thin septa with soap-bubble appearance on X-ray, cortex thin and expanded, no periosteal reaction

Treatment

Curettage, debridement, and in some cases radiation (cautiously)

Surgical excision with PMMA or bone grafting; Denosumab and bisphosphonates as adjunct therapy

Osteosarcoma (Option C): It is a malignant tumor that presents with mixed lytic-sclerotic lesions and periosteal reactions rather than a purely lytic, expansile lesion with a bloody aspirate.

Chondroblastoma (Option D): It is a rare benign tumor that affects the epiphysis, usually seen in younger patients, but it does not typically show a bloody aspirate or hemosiderin deposits on FNA.

questions.text: Codman's triangle is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Osteogenic sarcoma

 

Explanation:

  • Codman’s triangle is seen in Osteogenic sarcoma
  • The elevation of the periosteum in the form of a triangle is known as Codman's triangle.

Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma):

  • Most common primary malignant bone tumor of non-hematopoietic origin/ solid malignant bone tumor.
  • Age group: Bimodal age distribution peaking in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade.
  • Gender: Males >> Female

 

 

 

  • All osteosarcomas are aggressive and metastasize widely through the hematogenous route, typically to the lungs.
  • Despite its aggressiveness, it seldom penetrates the epiphyseal plate.

Histopathology: Anaplastic mesenchymal parenchyma with tumor cells surrounded by osteoid.

 

Clinical manifestation:

  • Worsening pain and swelling, particularly night pain.
  • Pathological fracture is rare.
  • On examination:
    • Shiny skin with prominent veins over swelling.
    • Poorly defined, warm, and tender swelling.
    • Adjacent joint movement may be limited due to swelling.
    • The tumor may compress neurovascular structures, causing symptoms.
    • Usually reactive enlargement of regional lymph nodes.
  • Associated syndromes with osteosarcoma development:
    • Li–Fraumeni (p53 tumor suppressor gene mutation)
    • Hereditary retinoblastoma syndromes
    • Rothmund–Thomson syndrome

 

X-ray findings of osteosarcoma:

  • Area of irregular destruction in the metaphysis. The cortex overlying the lesion is eroded.
  • Sun-ray appearance (aggressive periostitis): As the tumor grows into the overlying soft tissues new bone is laid down centrifugally along the blood vessels within the tumor.
  • Codman's triangle: Elevation of periosteum by the growing tumor in the form of a triangle.

CT scan is primarily used to assist with biopsy and disease staging.

 

Treatment

Combination of therapy:

  • Surgical amputation is the treatment of choice- complete removal of the tumor must be ensured. Limb-salvage procedures have become possible and popular.
  • Radiotherapy
  • Chemotherapy
    • Doxorubicin
    • Cisplatin
    • Ifosfamide
    • Methotrexate
  • Follow-up: Every 6-8 weeks. Evidence of recurrence of the primary tumor or appearance of the secondary (usually in the chest) is diagnosed early and treated.

Osteomyelitis (Options A), Aneurysmal bone cyst (Options B) and Chondrosarcoma (Options D) are not associated with Codman’s triangle.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic complaining of a painless lump on the lateral aspect of his left knee. The radiograph of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Osteochondroma

Explanation:

  • Osteochondroma, also known as exostosis, is characterized by an exophytic growth from the bone. This type of growth appears as a cauliflower-like structure in imaging studies.

Osteochondroma:

  • Benign cartilaginous neoplasms arising from physeal cartilage beneath the periosteum.
  • Growth via enchondral ossification, similar to normal bone development.
  • More common in males, usually appearing during adolescence.
  • Affects long bones, especially the femur and humerus.

Clinical Presentation

  • Usually presents as a painless mass.
  • Symptoms may include:
    • Formation of a bursa due to friction.
    • Activity-related discomfort.
  • Rare symptoms:
    • Neuropathic pain from nerve compression.
    • Sudden pain due to fracture.

Factors affecting malignant transformation:

  • Larger lesions with thicker cartilage caps (especially >1.5 cm).
  • More common in trunk lesions, and rare in extremities.
  • Suspicious changes in size or pain after skeletal maturity in MO patients.

Radiographic Appearance

  • Bony protuberance with well-defined borders.
  • Key radiographic features:
    • Cortex flaring into the osteochondroma. (Option B)
    • Thin outer cortex with inner cancellous structure.
    • Pedunculated (cauliflower-like summit) or broad sessile base.
    • Pedunculated lesions point away from the joint toward the diaphysis.


 

  • MRI findings:
    • Cartilaginous cap thickness, generally thicker in children and thins with age.

 

Enchondroma (Options A) presents with Asymmetric limb shortening, Swelling of fingers/toes and impaired movement of interphalangeal joints

Osteosarcoma (Options B) Sun-rays appearance is typically seen in osteosarcoma.

Osteomyelitis (Options D) shows periosteal new bone formation (periosteal reaction) by 7-10 days

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of intermittent administration of teriparatide?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Osteosarcoma :

  • Teriparatide is prescribed for treating medication-induced osteonecrosis, but it carries a risk of osteosarcoma, although this is rare. Patients with a higher baseline risk for osteosarcoma, including those with Paget disease of bone, unexplained elevations of alkaline phosphatase, open epiphyses, or prior radiation therapy involving the skeleton, should avoid using teriparatide.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteonecrosis of jaw: Osteonecrosis of the jaw can result from bisphosphonates and denosumab. Teriparatide, however, doesn't cause this condition; it's used to treat it.

Option B - Net bone loss: Teriparatide is not responsible for net bone loss or osteoporosis; instead, it is employed in treating postmenopausal and corticosteroid-induced osteoporosis.

Option D - Subtrochanteric fracture of the femur: Teriparatide does not cause subtrochanteric fracture of the femur

questions.text: A patient has a painless, palpable bony mass near the metaphysis of a long bone. X-ray done shows the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Osteochondroma:

  • Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that arises from the surface of a bone near the metaphysis and occurs in individuals during their growth years.
  • It presents as a painless, palpable bony mass that grows away from the joint.
  • On an X-ray, osteochondroma appears as a bony outgrowth with a cartilage cap.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Osteosarcoma:

  • Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that primarily affects the metaphysis of long bones.
  • It usually presents with a painful, rapidly growing mass.
  • On an X-ray, osteosarcoma typically appears as a destructive and irregular lesion with aggressive features such as periosteal reaction, cortical destruction and soft tissue extension.

Option B - Multiple myeloma:

  • Multiple myeloma is a hematological malignancy that affects plasma cells in the bone marrow.
  • It does not present as a palpable bony mass near the metaphysis of a long bone.
  • On an X-ray, multiple myeloma can show lytic lesions throughout the bone, often referred to as "punched-out" lesions.

Option D - Osteoid osteoma

  • Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor that causes localized pain that is relieved by NSAIDs.
  • It is typically found in the cortex of long bones, rather than near the metaphysis.
  • On an X-ray, osteoid osteoma appears as a small radiolucent nidus surrounded by dense sclerotic bone.

questions.text: A 14 year old male presents with a mushroom like tumor in the distal femur for the past 2 years. Which of the following features suggest its malignant transformation?

choices.text: Bone marrow is continuous with the parent bone
The cartilaginous growth goes towards the joint

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thickness of cartilage cap > 2cm

Explanation:

MRI showing thickness of cartilage cap >2 cms is suggestive of malignant transformation in Osteochondroma.

Osteochondroma:

Description
  • Also known as Exostosis
  • Most common primary benign bone tumor (but not a true bone tumor)
  • Benign cartilaginous neoplasms arising from physeal cartilage beneath the periosteum.
  • More common in males, usually appearing during adolescence.
  • Affects long bones, lower end of femur > upper end of tibia

Types
  • Solitary Osteochondroma
  • Multiple Osteochondromas (MO)

Clinical features
  • Painless mass- most common presentation
  • Pain: secondary to bursa formation/fracture/nerve compression

Radiographic Appearance
  • X-ray: Pedunculated cauliflower-like mass originating from metaphysis
  • MRI: used to assess cartilage thickness

Malignant transformation
  • Very rare
  • MRI showing cartilage thickness > 2 cms suggests malignant transformation (Option A)

Management
  • Asymptomatic cases: No treatment required
  • Symptomatic cases: Excision with biopsy

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 17-year-old male patient who visits the clinic with a painless lump on the outer side of his left knee, as depicted in the radiograph provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Osteochondroma

Explanation:

  • The radiograph shows a well-defined bony protuberance arising from the metaphysis of the distal femur, which is consistent with an osteochondroma.

 

Osteochondroma:

  • Benign cartilaginous neoplasms arising from physeal cartilage beneath the periosteum.
  • Growth via enchondral ossification, similar to normal bone development.
  • More common in males, usually appearing during adolescence.
  • Affects long bones, especially the femur and humerus.

Clinical Presentation

  • Usually presents as a painless mass.
  • Symptoms may include:
    • Formation of a bursa due to friction.
    • Activity-related discomfort.
  • Rare symptoms:
    • Neuropathic pain from nerve compression.
    • Sudden pain due to fracture.

Osteochondroma: X-ray, Treatment, and Complications

 

X-ray Appearance

  • Bony protuberance with distinct edges.
  • Widened host bone cortex extending into the osteochondroma.
  • Features may include:
    • Thin outer cortex, cancellous structure.
    • Pedunculated (cauliflower-like) or sessile base.
    • Pedunculated types grow away from joints, toward the diaphysis.

 

 

MRI to assess the cartilage cap thickness

  • Reserved for cases where malignant transformation is suspected.

 

 

Biopsy to rule out malignancy

  • Indicated without symptoms such as pain or rapid growth.

 

Treatment

  • Asymptomatic osteochondromas: No treatment required. (Option B)
  • Excision indicated for:
    • Large lesions causing pressure.
    • Concern for malignant transformation in adults.

 

Complications

Complication

Description

Painful bursa formation

Due to friction over the osteochondroma.

Activity-related discomfort

General discomfort with movement.

Nerve compression

Rare, may cause neuropathic symptoms.

Fracture

Uncommon, results in sudden pain.

Malignant transformation

Rare progression to chondrosarcoma, more likely with a cartilage cap >1.5 cm.

 

  • Malignant transformation risk factors:
    • Large cartilage cap (>1.5 cm on MRI).
    • Osteochondroma location: More common in the trunk, rare in extremities.
    • Risk Factors: Increased size or new pain after skeletal maturity, especially in Multiple Osteochondromas.

Enchondroma (Option A) are benign cartilaginous tumors that typically arise within the medullary canal of long bones, such as the proximal humerus or femur. They are usually asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on radiographs.

 

Chondroblastoma (Option B) are rare benign bone tumors that arise in the epiphysis of long bones, such as the proximal humerus or femur. On X-ray, they are seen as round or oval lytic lesions in the epiphysis.

 

Giant Cell Tumor (Option D) are benign bone tumors that typically arise in the epiphysis of long bones, such as the distal femur or proximal tibia. They may cause pain and swelling and erode adjacent bone, resulting in pathologic fractures. On radiographs, giant cell tumors appear as lytic lesions with a "soap bubble" appearance.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Given below is the X-ray image of the affected wrist. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Osteoclastoma:

  • Based on clinical presentation and the X-ray film provided, the most likely diagnosis is osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor. 
  • Osteoclastoma is a benign bone tumor that typically presents as a painful, gradually enlarging mass, most commonly located in the epiphyseal region of long bones. 
  • On imaging, osteoclastoma appears as a well-defined osteolytic lesion with areas of cortical thinning and expansion (soap bubble appearance). 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ewing's Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and young adults. It appears as a destructive bone lesion with an "onion skin" appearance. 

Option B - Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor commonly affecting adolescents and young adults. It appears as a destructive bone lesion with areas of new bone formation. 

Option D - Osteochondroma: Osteochondroma is characterized by a bony outgrowth that arises from the surface of the affected bone. X-ray imaging shows a bony projection with a cartilage cap.

questions.text: A child presents with difficulty in walking. On biopsy of the hip, some cells with grooved nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm are present. Which investigation would you order next?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - CD1a Marker:

  • The presence of cells with grooved nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm on hip biopsy suggests the possibility of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH), also known as histiocytosis X. CD1a marker is a specific immuno histochemical stain used to identify Langerhans cells, which are characteristic cells seen in LCH. Therefore, ordering the CD1a marker test would be the appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): While an MRI scan can provide detailed images of the hip joint and surrounding structures, it is not specific for diagnosing Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It may be useful in evaluating the extent of involvement or complications related to LCH, but it would not provide a definitive diagnosis.

Option B - Serum Calcium: Serum calcium levels may be elevated in some cases of Langerhans cell histiocytosis, but it is not a specific diagnostic test for this condition. Serum calcium alone cannot confirm or exclude the diagnosis of LCH.

Option C - Serum PTH (Parathyroid Hormone): Serum PTH levels are not directly related to the diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. This test is typically used in the evaluation of parathyroid gland function and calcium regulation and is not specific to LCH.

questions.text: The treatment for the condition given below is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Extended Curettage with Autograft:

  • Giant cell tumor is a benign but locally aggressive tumor that commonly affects the epiphysis of long bones. The treatment of choice for giant cell tumor is surgical intervention. Extended curettage refers to the removal of the tumor by scraping and scooping out the affected bone. Autograft involves using bone graft material from the patient's own body to fill the resulting defect and promote bone healing.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Extended Curettage with Allograft: Extended curettage with allograft is not the preferred treatment for giant cell tumors. Allograft refers to the use of bone graft material from a donor, which is not typically used in the treatment of giant cell tumors.

Option B - Bone Biopsy: Bone biopsy is a diagnostic procedure to obtain a sample of tissue for examination and confirmation of the diagnosis. While it may be performed as part of the diagnostic process, it is not the primary treatment for giant cell tumors.

Option C - Curettage: Curettage alone is not considered sufficient for the treatment of giant cell tumors. Extended curettage, as mentioned in option D, is a more comprehensive approach.

questions.text: Identify the following condition
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Osteosarcoma:

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common type of cancer occurring in long bones and it’s common amongst children in 2nd decade. It is a metaphyseal tumor , usually located at Distal end of femur.  It has a bimodal presentation and is the most radioresistant tumor

  • Charecterstics: Codman triangle as seen in image (from elevation of periosteum) or sunburst pattern on x-ray (think of an osteocod [bone fish] swimming in the sun).

  • Treatment ; Neoadjuvent chemotherapy followed by surgery/ limb ablation

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ewing Sarcoma: Although Ewing sarcoma is also a bone-mediated tumor, it commonly affects pelvis, ribs, spine and long bones as opposed to Osteosarcoma which only affects the long bones of the arms and legs and the x–ray image is of the femur proving it to be the wrong answer.

Option C - Osteiod Osteoma: In case of Osteiod Osteoma the x-ray imaging shows presence of nidus surrounded by sclerosis, which is not indicating the x-ray image in the question. Hence it’s a wrong choice.

Option D - GCT: GCT, i.e., Giant Cell Tumors are typically found at the ends of the long bones and extend into the epiphysis to surface of the joint, whereas the images show a tumor which is not located at the end of the bone, hence this is a wrong choice.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents to the orthopedician with complaints of painful swelling below the knee joint. An X-Ray was obtained which is given below. Which of the following is the preferred treatment modality for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A - Extended curettage and bone grafting:

  • Given the X-ray image showing a soap bubble appearance indicative of a giant cell tumor (GCT). Extended curettage involves the thorough removal of the tumor along with the surrounding affected tissue, followed by filling the resultant cavity with a bone graft. In the case of giant cell tumors (GCTs), extended curettage is the preferred treatment approach to achieve local control and decrease the risk of recurrence.

Treatment Options:

  • Extended curettage and bone grafting: This is the primary treatment for most GCTs.
  • Denosumab: Denosumab, a monoclonal antibody, is used as a treatment option for unresectable or recurrent GCTs. It helps reduce tumor size and control symptoms.
  • Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy may be used as an adjuvant treatment after surgery or as a palliative option for unresectable or recurrent cases.
  • Surgical stabilization: In cases of significant structural compromise or fractures, surgical stabilization techniques like internal fixation with plates and screws or intramedullary nailing may be employed.
  • Salvage procedures: Extensive or recurrent GCTs may require salvage procedures such as en bloc resection (removal of the tumor and surrounding tissues in one piece) or joint replacement.
  • Adjuvant chemotherapy: Adjuvant chemotherapy is rarely used for GCTs, typically in cases of metastatic disease or extensive unresectable tumors.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Simple Curettage and Bone Grafting: Simple curettage, which involves the removal of the tumor without extensive removal of surrounding tissue, is generally not sufficient for giant cell tumors (GCTs).

Option C - Radiofrequency Ablation: Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) is not typically considered the primary treatment modality for giant cell tumors (GCTs). While it may be used in certain cases as a minimally invasive treatment option, extended curettage is generally preferred to achieve complete tumor removal.

Option D - Radical Excision: Radical excision involves the complete removal of the tumor along with a wide margin of healthy tissue. While radical excision may be necessary for certain aggressive or malignant tumors, it is not the preferred treatment for most giant cell tumors (GCTs)

questions.text: A 35 year old man when presented with a gradual progressive swelling , was diagnosed with  Adamantinoma. Which of the following bone  is typically affected by this tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Tibia:

  • Adamantinoma is a rare primary bone tumor that typically affects the tibia (shinbone). It arises from the epithelial tissue within the bone. Adamantinoma is most commonly seen in the diaphysis (shaft) of the tibia, but it can also occur in other long bones.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Adamantinoma most commonly presents in young to middle-aged adults, typically between the ages of 20 and 40.
  • The most common site of involvement is the tibia, particularly the diaphysis (shaft) region.
  • Patients often present with localized pain, swelling, and a palpable mass in the affected bone.
  • Rarely, pathological fractures can occur.

Histopathology:

  • Adamantinoma is characterized by the presence of biphasic cellular components: epithelial-like cells and fibrous or osteofibrous stroma.
  • The epithelial-like cells form glandular or tubular structures resembling the enamel organ of developing teeth.
  • The stroma is composed of fibrous tissue with varying degrees of osteoid or bone formation.
  • Microscopic examination and immunohistochemistry are used to confirm the diagnosis.

Radiological Findings:

  • On X-ray, Adamantinoma typically presents as a lytic lesion within the affected bone, often with associated cortical thinning or expansion.
  • The lesion may exhibit a "soap-bubble" appearance due to areas of bone destruction and reactive bone formation.
  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can provide detailed information about the extent of the tumor and its relationship to surrounding structures.

Treatment:

  • Surgical resection is the mainstay of treatment for Adamantinoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Radius: Adamantinoma primarily affects the tibia, not the radius.

Option B - Humerus: Adamantinoma primarily affects the tibia, not the humerus.

Option C - Femur: Adamantinoma primarily affects the tibia, not the femur.

questions.text: The following X-ray shows a lytic lesion of the lower limb. The biopsy shows fibroblastic proliferation, osteoclast and inflammatory cells. From the given options, the most likely diagnosis that can be inferred from the above clinical picture is
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Giant Cell Tumour:

  • The clinical picture described in the question suggests a lytic lesion of the lower limb with histological features of fibroblastic proliferation, osteoclasts, and inflammatory cells. These findings are characteristic of a giant cell tumour. Giant cell tumours are benign but locally aggressive bone tumours that commonly occur in the epiphyseal regions of long bones, including the lower limb. They typically present as lytic lesions on X-ray and are characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells along with fibroblasts and inflammatory cells on histopathological examination.

Option A - Aneurysmal Bone Cyst: Aneurysmal bone cysts are typically characterized by blood-filled cystic spaces and are not associated with fibroblastic proliferation or inflammatory cells.

Option C - Chondroblastoma: Chondroblastomas are benign bone tumors composed of chondroblasts and typically present with calcified or ossified areas. They do not exhibit fibroblastic proliferation or osteoclasts.

Option D - Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis: Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is characterized by the presence of Langerhans cells, which are dendritic cells, on histopathological examination. LCH may present with lytic bone lesions, but the presence of fibroblastic proliferation and osteoclasts is not typical for LCH.

questions.text: What is the potential diagnosis of the patient with a swelling around his knee, whose X-ray image is given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Giant Cell Tumor:

  • Giant cell tumor (GCT) is a locally aggressive, benign bone tumor that primarily affects young adults. It commonly occurs in the long bones, such as the distal femur or proximal tibia. GCT appears as a locally destructive lesion with a characteristic "soap bubble" or "honeycomb" appearance on imaging. 
  • Treatment for giant cell tumors may involve surgical curettage, followed by adjuvant treatments such as bone grafting, and local adjuvants.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Solitary Bone Cyst:

  • A solitary bone cyst, also known as a unicameral bone cyst, is a benign bone lesion that commonly occurs in children and young adults. It typically affects the long bones, such as the femur or humerus. Solitary bone cysts appear as fluid-filled cavities within the bone, causing expansion and thinning of the cortical bone. However, they do not usually result in the specific finger deformity described in the question. Solitary bone cysts are typically asymptomatic and incidentally discovered in imaging studies. They are usually managed conservatively, with monitoring of the lesion's size and possible intervention if symptoms or complications arise.

Option B - Aneurysmal Bone Cyst:

  • An aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is a benign, locally aggressive bone lesion that most commonly occurs in children and young adults. It can affect any bone in the body, including the long bones and the spine. ABCs appear as expansile, cystic lesions filled with blood, which can cause cortical thinning and bone destruction. However, finger involvement is relatively uncommon for aneurysmal bone cysts. They are more commonly found in the long bones or vertebrae. Treatment for aneurysmal bone cysts may involve surgical intervention, such as curettage or embolization, depending on the size, location, and symptoms associated with the lesion.

Option D - Osteoblastoma:

  • Osteoblastoma is a rare, benign bone tumor that usually affects young individuals. It commonly occurs in the spine and long bones but can occur in any bone. Osteoblastomas appear as well-defined, eccentric lesions with a central nidus surrounded by reactive bone. Finger involvement is relatively rare for osteoblastoma. They are more commonly found in weight-bearing bones. The mainstay of treatment for osteoblastoma's is surgical excision, and the prognosis is generally good.
